title: Statue of limitations on 2nd trust deeds
question: My house went into foreclosure 2 years ago with a 1st and a 2nd trust deeds. Is it true that after 4 years the banks can't come after me for the unpaid debts?
answers:
Yes. it is true that creditors must initiate lawsuit within 4 years of sale. Has sale actually taken place? If no sale has taken place, statute has not begun to run.
You may be protected by both the statute of limitations (4 years) and California anti-deficiency statute.
Consult BK counsel.

The statute of limitations on an installment note is frequently longer than most people realize. When it comes to notes secured by deeds of trust on real property, the issue becomes even more complicated.

You will need to consult a real property lawyer who can review the note and other facts, including the conduct of both parties, for an answer to your question. One thing is usually certain: it is substantially longer than 4 years from the first missed installment payment.

For more on this issue see this blog post: "Promissory Notes and the Statute of Limitations" at http://mrdaymude.com/statute-of-limitations-and-installment-notes.

Depending on other facts, you may have other defenses under anti-deficiency statutes. On this issue see this blog post: "Anti-deficiency Statutes Summarized" at http://mrdaymude.com/anti-deficiency-statutes-summarized.

Any lender that is entitled to sue (yours may not be) must do so within the four year statute of limitations. The issue will be when the statute starts to run. You would be taking the position that it started when you first failed to pay an installment, but the facts may show that the statute did not start to run until a later date. You should have an attorney review the documents
